Literature Review: The endometrium, a dynamic and highly specialized tissue, has long fascinated researchers due to its unique ability to regenerate and its propensity to form scars following disruptions. This review aims to summarize the current understanding of the mechanisms underlying regenerative success and failure in the endometrium, with a focus on the determinants of these disparate repair processes. We will discuss the role of stem cells, the impact of inflammation, and the effects of mechanical stress on endometrial regeneration, as well as the consequences of fibrosis and scarring. Our analysis will be grounded in a comprehensive review of the literature, including studies on human, nonhuman primate, and rodent models of endometrial disruption events such as menstruation, pregnancy, Asherman syndrome, and intrauterine adhesion. By elucidating the complex interplay of factors that govern endometrial regeneration and scarring, we hope to shed light on the fundamental mechanisms of mammalian regeneration and its implications for reproductive health.
